ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: It was only a live virtual lecture
self studying
In addition, there was also a twice-weekly live virtual lecture with the section instructor. I also attended peer tutoring sessions.
Recorded lecture videos plus live virtual classes that were part lecture part interactive.
Both virtual, asynchronous videos and an in-person lecture.
Live virtual lecture, plus recorded lectures to view before class.
N/A
I'm not sure if it counted as a lecture because we watched videos before class and then did practice and review of those topics in the virtual class.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Through the instructor's carefully planned classes I was able to develop a more precise and conceptual based insight into the material of Math 120. Application of the material was practiced in homework, but during class the conceptual information about the current topic was highlighted.

I gained the knowledge that the intro math sequence here is horrible. There is a very very big reliance on self-studying and the problem sets do not help with understanding, rather, they help with creating busy work through stupid trig integrals that should be left in calculus 2.
I believe that I developed a greater ability to spatially visualize three-dimensional shapes in my mind, which hopefully will be an asset to me going forward.
Multivariable Calculus. Exactly what was on the syllabus, no more and no less.
How to solve multivariable calculus problems quickly.
Multivariable calculus.
Partial derivatives, multiple integrals, the Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals and all of its higher-order variants.
I learned that it's okay (and probably more responsible) to use tutors and go to office hours. Obviously, I got better at math in general and, over time, it got easier to learn math online.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: Very interactive, during every class break out rooms via Zoom were used to discuss problems assigned in class. Weaknesses: It would be nice to have practiced a little bit more the application of Math 120 during the lectures instead of only focusing on the main idea of each chapter.

I did not like this class one bit. There were many weaknesses in the assistance in understanding concepts and the live lectures were nothing more than a regurgitation of the assigned textbook reading and videos.

Strengths: 
- recorded lectures were very straightforward and very good/understandable
- exams seemed fair to me

Weaknesses: 
- sometimes it was unclear (at least to me) what resources allowed on PSETs, and it might be nice to clearly establish that before the class begins
- some of the PSETs seemed overly computational, to the point where I felt that it was overshadowing my experience of actually gaining practice with the concepts
The point of this course is to get people through Calculus III and it did that well. John Hall is a great teacher while of course the graduate students are less advanced.

The strengths were the responsiveness of the instructor and the abundance of resources for preparing for midterms, as well as the several peer tutor office hours. Perhaps one weakness was the frequent algebra mistakes that made some content slightly hard to follow.

This course successfully got through a lot of material in a short amount of time, but I would have appreciated more step-by-step help during live lectures. I was confused for about half of each class, so didn't really enjoy class.

The review sessions, Ximera, and all of the recorded lectures and practice exams were extremely helpful. Maybe one more practice exam could be added but other than that the umbrella course was structured very well. Also more initial steering/guidance for the project would be helpful, since project topics were comprised mostly of more difficult mathematics.

I think it was nice to have the lectures before and then a review of what we should have learned from the videos in class. However, with easier subjects, it could be a little redundant to sit through a class about something we already knew.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The use of break out rooms to further discussion and to bounce off ideas among one another on how to approach the problems assigned succeeded very well.
I don't think they really tried to practice anything geared towards this pandemic.

Success: 
- recorded lectures > they were very clear
- peer tutoring sessions

I would say there was nothing about virtual engagement of this class that was a significant weakness, although perhaps offering some assistance to people searching to form study groups for PSETS might be helpful.
The recorded lecture videos were good. It was hard to stay engaged in a live virtual math classroom, though: most people had their cameras off.
I would say that breakout rooms should be modified, since it is not always the case that all students are actively trying to participate in them.

The lecture style of the class worked well for online learning, but the breakout rooms (to work on in-class problems) weren't very helpful. Because some people understood the lesson really well and others didn't, almost no conversation happened, and I didn't learn much from these breakout room sessions. I think working those problems with the entire class would have been better.
Online recorded lectures were helpful, sections can also be online in future years since it is a very convenient/efficient format for teaching Math 120.

I liked how small my section was - it made it easy to ask questions and contribute to class discussions. I also enjoyed the use of breakout rooms so that we could get to know our classmates better. We were encouraged to get each other's contact information from our professor which made it easy to be collaborative on the problem sets.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend the course for those interested in further pursuing a background in STEM and prefer a more conceptually focused start to multi-variable calculus, than application based.
No. Only take it if you must. If you are a prospective math major, take 230 instead.
Yes, especially if you are looking to gain a greater ability to spatially visualize 3-D graphs. Also, I assume it is probably necessary to take more upper level math classes.
Yes, because you probably need to. Multivariable calculus is important for most students, so if you need to take Calc III then MATH 120 is the way to do it.
I would recommend it because they'll acquire skills needed in other science/social science courses. Knowing the theory of multivariable calculus without the applications can only get you so far.
I would recommend this class to someone who needs to take multivariable calc as a major requirement. While the course was very difficult, I did learn multivariable calc really well.
Yes, especially if you already have some Multivariable background, this class will help cement it and fill in gaps. If you are coming from AP Calculus, you will need to work harder on your own.

Probably not, unless they needed a high level of math. I struggled a lot at the beginning of the course, and it took me a lot of time to complete the assignments. It was a good math class, but if I was just talking to a random student, I probably wouldn't suggest this course.
